titleStmt.title: Mercurius publicus: comprising the sum of forraign intelligence ...[no.34 (16 Aug-23 Aug 1660)]
Mercurius publicus (London, England : 1659)
titleStmt.author: Muddiman, Henry, fl.1659-1666, editor.
Dury, Giles editor.
Newcomb, Thomas, d. 1681 or 2, publisher.

biblFull.extent: v. Began with numb. 1 (29 Dec. 1659-5 Jan. 1660); ceased with numb. 33 (13-20 Aug. 1663).

notesStmt.note: Subtitle varies: 1660, "... comprising the sum of forraign intelligence"; 1661-1663, "... comprising the sum of all affairs now in agitation."
By Henry Muddiman and Giles Dury. Cf. Nelson and Seccombe.
Printed variously by: John Macock, Thomas Newcomb, Richard Hodgkinson, D. Maxwell, Peter Lillicrap, James Cottrell.
Numb. 43 (18-25 Oct. 1660) is a second copy of The Parliamentary intelligencer for those dates, mistakenly titled Mercurius publicus.
Thomason collection does not have complete run.
Reels listed in chronological order of serial publication; holdings dispersed throughout collection.
Reproduction of the originals in the British Library.
Enumeration begins again at numb. 1 annually.
No issue numbered 52 in 1660, no issue numbered 44 in 1661; chronology is continuous.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Numb. 34 Mercurius Publicus, COMPRISING The Sum of Forraign Intelligence: WITH The Affairs now in Agitation in England, Scotland, and Ireland. For Information of the People. Publi≈øhed by Order. From Thur≈øday Augu≈øt 16. to Thur≈øday Augu≈øt 23. 1660.
White-hall.
div.p: THis following Addre≈øs was pre≈øented to His Majesty, in the Clo≈øet at White-hall, on Friday the tenth of Augu≈øt, 1660. by George Wilde Doctor of Divinity, accompanyed with Sir William Haward Knight, Gentleman in Ordinary of His Maje≈øties Privie Chamber, and the≈øe of the Clergie, Doctor Pear≈øon, Rich. Randall, Tho. Mulca≈øter, Tho. Packenham, Edw. Lorkin, and Jo. Worthington.

body.head: To the Kings Mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty. The mo≈øt humble and joyful Congratulatory Addre≈øs of divers Rectors, Vicars, and others of the Clergy in the County of Surrey.

opener.salute: May it plea≈øe Your mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty.

body.p: THe pre≈øent Mercies we enjoy through the Infinite Go ‚Ä¢ dne≈øs and Bounty of our God, are wonderful in our eyes! No Power but Omnipotency could extricate us out of tho≈øe woful Confu≈øions, and lamentable Labyrinths of Ruine, into which our National and Per≈øonal ≈øins had ≈øo deeply and de≈øervedly plunged us. For whereas we were not long ≈øince de≈øpairing of ever beholding Your Maje≈øties ble≈ø≈øed Face in Peace, and our troubled thoughts were, That there was no path for Your Maje≈øty to walk unto Your Royal Throne but blood and fire, and pillars of ≈ømoke; Lo, now to our very amazement, it hath plea≈øed the great King of Heaven and Earth [of whom Your Maje≈øties Per≈øon is an expre≈øs Image, and lively character in Your Kingly Power and Soveraigne Authority] to make way thereunto without ≈øhedding in the Field one drop of precious Chri≈øtian blood. Nay, he hath cau≈øed tho≈øe very Swords, which were lately unnaturally and violently drawn again≈øt the life of Your mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, to be ready and willing to be drawn now for You, and hath con≈øtrained Your mo≈øt Implacable Enemies to ≈øubmit to Your Maje≈øties Mercy.

And now we hope, that as the Lord hath ≈øweetly enclined Your Maje≈øties heart, like Your Father of ever ble≈ø≈øed Memory, to pa≈øs by every In≈øolency committed again≈øt Your Princely Sacred Per≈øon: ≈øo he will give every mi≈øled and undutiful Subject a relenting ≈øpirit, to mourn heartily for their wicked di≈øloyalties, and to ≈øupplicate as to God's infinite Mercy, ≈øo likewi≈øe for Your Maje≈øties mo≈øt Gracious Pardon, which as we humbly begg'd by the late Act of the Commons in Parliament; ≈øo we do by this our Addre≈øs ≈øignifie our joyful acceptance thereof at Your Maje≈øties mo≈øt Clement and Gracious Hands. And henceforth we ≈øhall ≈øtrive in our Prayers with the mo≈øt High God, to
grant to every Soul within Your Maje≈øties Dominions, true grace to manife≈øt their fear of him, by their Honour and Obedience towards you.

And as we heartily de≈øire to ≈øhew our ≈øelves Your dutiful Subjects, ≈øo we do not doubt of finding Your Maje≈øty an Indulgent Nur≈øing Father, to carry us in Your Bo≈øom, to Cover us with Your Wings of Protect ‚Ä¢ on, to Rule us with Your Scepter of Righteou≈øne≈øs, to Defend us with Your Sword of Might, to Lead us by Your mo≈øt Holy Princely Ex ‚Ä¢ mple to all Piety and Vertue, that we may be an happy People under a mo≈øt Ble≈ø≈øed and Glorious KING.

p.hi: And now the Mighty Coun≈øellor from above in≈øpire Your Maje≈øties Royal heart, and make you as wi≈øe as a glorious Angel, that You may di≈øcern between Good and Evil, and be able with your great Wi≈ødom, to heal the Sores, and cures the Wounds of the≈øe Your di≈øtracted Kingdoms; that You may with an Invincible Courage, under God, In≈øtrumentally fini≈øh the great and Miraculous Work that he hath begun for Your Majesty and your people, in Restoring Your Royal Per≈øon to all Your Hereditary and due Rights; Your Parliaments to their known Priviledge; Your Subjects to their Charters and ju≈øt Liberties; the Chu ‚Ä¢ ch and Clergie to their ‚Ä¢ andient Leg ‚Ä¢ l Government, Or ‚Ä¢ er, Beauty, Dignity, and Splendor‚ñ™ That all Po≈øterities to come, as well as this pre≈øent Generation, may ri≈øe up to call You CHARLES The Ble≈ø≈øed King.

Now the Lord Love You, Delight in You, give You length of Days, with an Un-interrupted Pro≈øperity, Protect Your Sacred Per≈øon from all ≈øecret Con≈øpiracies, di≈øcover and convert Your Enemies, Increa≈øe and Multiply Your Friends, Set Your Throne in the Hearts of all Your People, Ble≈øs Your Government; and when Your Maje≈øties long and mo≈øt Happy Reign ≈øhall expire, grant that there may not be wanting u ‚Ä¢ e of the Royal L ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e to
Sit on Your Throne after You, and receive Your Immortal Soul into His Heavenly Kingdom, there to wear an Immarcelcible Crown of Glory.

closer.signed:
This is, and ≈øhall be the continual, hearty, zealous, fervent, loyal Prayer of us Your Maje≈øties mo≈øt faithful, mo≈øt obedient, and mo≈øt loving Subjects,
Thomas Turner, Rector of Fetcham. S. T. D.
John Hacket, Rector of Cheame. S. T. D.
George Wilde, L L. D. &c.
John Pear≈øon, D. D.
Ralph Cooke Rector of Burstow, S. T. D
John Harris, S. T. B. And many others.

div.head: We≈øtmin≈øter.
div.p: That Noble and accompli≈øhed per≈øon Francis Lord Newport, Baron of High-Arcal (who with his whole Family hath done and ≈øuffered ≈øo much for his Maje≈øty, as well out, as in the Tower of London) is now made Governour of his Maje≈øties Ca≈øtle at Lualow, where his Lord≈øhips own Company of Foot are a≈ø≈øign'd, be≈øides what other Command his Lord≈øhip hath over the County.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENTS.
div.p: An Expedient for taking away all Impo≈øitions, and for rai≈øing a Revenue without Taxes. By Francis Cradock Merchant. Printed for Henry Scile, His MAJESTIES Stationer.

An Hawking Bagg, wherein was ≈øome ≈ømall Linnen, a Letter-Ca≈øe, and Letters, with other Writings, was lo≈øt neer Grantham,
in Lincoln≈øhire, If any have found it, and bring it to the George at Stanford, or to the Naggs head in James's street Covent Garden, he ≈øhall receive ten pounds for his pains.

We are commanded to give notice again, That His MAJESTY for divers weighty Rea≈øons as well as the extraordinary heat of the ≈øea≈øon) will forbear touching any more of tho≈øe who have the Evil, till further Order; of which we ≈øhall give you timely Adverti≈øement.

We mu≈øt now acquaint you with a particular from Ireland, which had we it not from unque≈øtionable credit, we ≈øhould not mention. In the Town of Dundalkchin ( ‚Ä¢ n Engli≈øh Ca≈øtle-Town) in the County of Louth, there is a chief and very ancient Seat belonging to the Noble Family of Bellew, Sir Chri≈øtopher Bellew being the four and twentieth Knight of that Family lineally de≈øcended, all faithful Subjects to the Crown. About this Hou≈øe and Town were many A≈øh-Trees, wherein many thou≈øand Rooks did con≈øtantly breed, but when the late troubles began, about eighteen years ≈øince, all the Rooks quitted the place, which had been their con≈øtant habitation Winter and Summer, for above three hundred years, and were never ≈øince di≈øcovered in that place till the end of April la≈øt (when our Gracious Soveraign's Re≈øtauration was vi≈øible) at which time many thou≈øand Rooks came again to the ≈øame place, though the Trees were mo≈øt of them cut down; where for want of Trees to re≈øt on, the greater part ≈øa ‚Ä¢ e upon Hedges, and Banks of Ditches, ≈øpreading them≈øelves upon the Mote-hill, whereof all the C ‚Ä¢ untry took notice, and remembring when they fled, concluded their return to be an Omen of his Maje≈øties ≈øpeedy and happy Re≈øtauration.

Whereas the enemies of Epi≈øcopacy have traduc'd George Baker, (Chaplain to the late Primate of Ireland, and now Elect Bi≈øhop of
Waterford) as gu ‚Ä¢ lty of ≈øome mi≈ødemeanors in Preaching a Funeral Sermon in St Margarets, We≈øtmin≈øter, at the Funeral of Mr. Chri≈øtopher Walker,
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ which Church the ≈øaid Mr. Baker never preached, nor was there pre≈øent that day:
The Certificate of the Inhabitants of St Margarets We≈øtmin≈øter.
WHereas at the Funeral of M. Chri≈øtoph. Walker late of S. Margarets We≈øtmin≈øter, decea≈øed, ≈øolemniz'd at the ≈øaid Church July 19 la≈øt, there was a Sermon then preached by Mr. Baker of Maribone. We who≈øe names are hereunto ≈øub≈øcribed do te≈øtifie, that we were pre≈øent at the preaching of the ≈øaid ≈øermon, & that M. Baker of Maribone did preach the ≈øame, and not M. Geo. Baker, Chaplain to the late Lord Primate of Armach, as hath bin ≈ølanderou≈øly reported. In te≈øtimony whereof we have hereunto put our hands this fourth day of Augu≈øt 1660.
Tho. Kirk, Bryan Barnaby, Adam Prince, John Belchamber, Bartholomew Pylman, Will. Blagrave, Tho. Kirke junior, George Walker, Joyce Walker, widow of the decea≈øed.

div.head: London.
div.p: You may remember when the Rump la≈øt lifted up it ≈øelf, a Per≈øon adventured to blot out that mon≈øtrous In≈øcription which the bloody Rumpers had cau≈øed to be ≈øet over the place where ≈øtood the Statue of that glorious Martyr King Charles the fir≈øt; ≈øeveral per≈øons a≈ø≈øumed that hone≈øt Enterpri≈øe to them≈øelves, as there will never want ≈øuch as will own a good action when crown'd with ≈øucce≈øs: Know therefore, that it was Mr. Michael Darby now Painter to the Company of Mercers, who hearing how three eminent Members of that Society were troubled to behold that infamous Super≈øcription: the ≈øaid Mr. Darby freely offered him≈øelf to blot it out, engaging to do it, before he ≈ølept, and accordingly performed it at a full afternoon Exchange time; who as ≈øoon as he had fin ‚Ä¢ ≈øhed it, with a loudly voice ≈øaid, God ≈øave King Charls th ‚Ä¢ ≈øecond; for which Act of Loyalty he hath had the Honour to beautifie the Statues of our gracious King and his glorious Father, with the in ‚Ä¢ criptions under written.

q.p: CAROLUS PRIMUS. Monarcharum Mag. Britanniae Secundus, Franciae & Hiberniae Rex, Martyr ad Coelum mi≈ø≈øus penultimo, Jan. Anno Dom. MDCXLVIII.
The Scepter in his right Hand, A Church in his left Arm, A Globe at his left Foot, and on his Shield, MAGNA CHARTA.
CAROLUS SECUNDUS. Monarcharum Mag. Britanniae Tertius, Franciae & Hibernia Rex, Aetat. ≈øuae Anno. trice≈øsimo, Regni duodecimo, Re≈øtaurationis primo, Anno Dom. MDCLX.
The Scepter in his right Hand, In his left the Globe, and on his Shield, AMNESTIA.

div.head: From Lemp≈øter.
div.p: Major Theophilus Hart, Major to the Earl of Sandwich drew together four Troops of Hor≈øe of his Lord≈øhips Regiment neer Litchfield, where after he had at large declared the weight and importance of a ≈øolemn Oath, he tendred to them the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy, which they all took with very much alacrity. Thence he rode to the other two Troops then at Kedderm in≈øter, where after the like Exhortation, they all with like cheerfulne≈øs took the fore≈øaid Oaths.

div.head: Hamburg, Augu≈øt 9.
div.p: La≈øt night a little before the Gates of this City were ≈øhut up, arrived here Chri≈øtina Queen of Sweden, with a great Train of Followers, it is ≈øaid ≈øhe intends to make ≈øome ≈øtay here, but of that there is no certainty. The Con≈øederate Forces in Hol≈øtein and Pomerania (as the report goeth) are like to lie yet a moneth longer in their Quarters. Letters from Copenhagen intimate, that affairs were put there into a quiet po≈øture, the Danes being now at ≈øome ea≈øe, ≈øince the Swedes have quitted their I≈ølands, and are all gone over into Schonen, who≈øe tran≈øportation being much furthered by the Holland Vice Admiral de Ruyter, his Maje≈øty of Denmark hath given him many thanks, be≈øides a noble pre≈øent. This Vice Admiral is now in readine≈øs to repair with his Fleet into Holland with the fir≈øt opportunity. They w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e from Dantzick, that the ≈øeveral Ratifications of peace were brought thither, but were not yetmutally interchanged. The Plague beg ‚Ä¢ ns to be brief again in tho≈øe parts,

On Saturday the 18 in≈øtant, his Maje≈øty gave his Royal a≈ø≈øent to an Act for the continuation of the levying and payment of the Impo≈øition called Exci≈øe (as al≈øo all Arrears thereof from Farmers ≈øince 1657. and from Merchants and other per≈øons ≈øince March 25. 1658.) by and to Nathaniel Manton, Benjamin Goodwin, Thomas Lenthal, and Edward Wingate E≈øquires, appointed Commi≈ø≈øioners for the Grand E ‚Ä¢ ci≈øe, from the 20 of Augu≈øt 1600. inclu≈øively to the 5 of December next following. The ‚Ä¢ ame Act doth appoint Sir Rich. Brown, Sir Will. Dawley, Iohn Bi ‚Ä¢ ch, Will. Prynne, Edward King, and Robert Scawen E≈øquires, Commi≈øsioners for Appeals and regulating the Exci≈øe.

Provided all ≈øorts of Oyls, Wines, Tobacco's of the Engli≈øh Plantations, Silks, Tapes, Inckles, Linnens, Pan-Tiles, Playing Cards, Girdles, and Cabinets of all ≈øorts, Copperice, Hops, Lace, imported after the 24 of Iuly, be di≈øcharged of that duty.

div.head: Riga in Lie ‚Ä¢ land, July 10.
div.p: The Duke of Courland having been magnificently treated by our Governor and Magi≈øtrates, departed hence the ≈øeventh of this month with all his Family and Retinue to go for Libaw; he was met and received by the way by a Captain, in the head of a Troop of 300 hor≈øe.

div.head: Adverti≈øement.
div.p: MO≈øt Excellent and approved Dentrifices, to ≈øcowre and clean≈øe the Tee ‚Ä¢ h making them white as Ivory, pre≈øerves from the Tooth-ach, ≈øo that being con≈øtantly u≈øed, the parties u≈øing it, are never troubled with the Toothach? It fa≈øtens the Teeth, ≈øweetens the Breath, and pre≈øerves the Gums and Mouth from Cankets and Impo≈øthumes, and being beaten to powder, and drunk in Wine, or any other drink, is a good remedy for any flux or Lask. Invented and made by Robert Turner, the onely Author of them, and are onely to be had at the Hou≈øe of Thomas Rookes, Stationer, at the Holy Lamb at the Ea≈øt-end of St. Pauls Church, near the School, in Sealed Papers.

LO≈øt out of a Pa≈øture-ground from Lathbury by Newport Pagnel, the tenth of Augu≈øt, a black Gelding of Henry Andrews E≈øq about fifteen hands high, ≈øix years old, blows more then ordinary in his Trotting: If any can give notice to Mr. Anthony Bercher at the Black Swan in Cheap≈øide, or to Mr. Richard Fooks in Newport-Pagnel, they ≈øhall be well ≈øatisfied.

A White Gelding about fourteen handfuls high, ten years old, ≈øomewhat hollow ey'd, a coller-gall cro≈øs his brea≈øt, a little heated in the f ‚Ä¢ refeet, hath all his paces compleat, ≈øtollen or ≈øtrayed from the Mar≈øh near Fox-Hall, on Thur≈øday night the ≈øixteenth in≈øtant: If any one can give notice to Mr. Tho. Spence at the Gra≈øs-hopper in the Strand, an Uphol≈øter or to Mr. Hendricks at the Portcullis and Swan at Lambeth, he ≈øhall have Twenty ≈øhillings for his pains.

div.head: From Candia, July 16.
div.p: The Ba≈øhaw Governor of Canea, perceiving the time to draw nigh that a ≈øiege would be laid to this place, he hath cau≈øed all the Armes to be taken away from the Inhabitants, fearing le≈øt they might keep ≈øecret Intelligence with the Venetians; He hath likewi≈øe ≈øhipt away many little and un≈øerviceable per≈øons.

div.head: From Vienna, July 30.
div.p:
His Imperial Maje≈øty hath been hunting of Stags about Gratz, where he killed about 100 of them. His Naje≈øty is now to goe with a ≈ømall retinue into Carinthia, and Craine,
to take homage of tho≈øe Countries, the re≈øt of his followers are to return hither. From Upper Hungaria it is certified, that the Count of Serin hath received orders from his Imperial Maje≈øty to withdraw his Forces from the Fort of Cani≈øcha; But the Turkes are not minded to quit Tran≈øylvania, till tho≈øe 500000 Florens, which Barchay had rai≈øed from the States of that Countrey, be repayed them, the mo≈øt part of which ≈øumme he hath di≈øbur≈øt upon Levies and Ammunition for the War, and therefore doth yet de≈øire more of the Countrey. The Hungarian and the Ragozian Garri≈øon in Great Waradin ≈øolicits earne≈øtly for a ≈øpeedy relief, at lea≈øt, that they could be provided but with 3 or 4 expert Gunners, becau≈øe the Turks are fully re≈øolved to lay ≈øiege to that place, whereof notice hath been given to his Imperial Maje≈øty at Gratz by a Courrier. At the beginning of Augu≈øt his Maje≈øty intends to ≈øet his Journey forwards for Carinthia, in order whereunto all nece≈ø≈øary provi≈øion is made, Hor≈øes and Mules for Carriages being appointed to attend his Maje≈øty at Gratz. The Colonels Stellmacher, Sparre and Priami have received orders to advance with their Regiments out of Bohemia towards Lintz, whence it is thought, they will proceed on their march hitherwards, and ≈øo for Hungaria, where, (in regard the Turkes have ≈øate downe with their maine Body before Great-Woradin) the Imperiali≈øts have likewi≈øe taken their Head-Quarters and begin to encampe them≈øelves, being found at their la≈øt mu≈øter about Ratkomatz, to be of the number of ten thou≈øand men, there hath nothing as yet pa≈ø≈øed between the≈øe two Armies, ≈øave onely, that the parties on both ≈øides doe now and then encounter one another.

Since our la≈øt News from the Army, be plea≈øed to take this account of two Regiments belonging to two per≈øons of Honor; the fir≈øt is that Regiment, which formerly belonged to Col. Herbert Morley and is now commanded by the Right Honorable the Earl of Peterborough, who≈øe Capt. Lieutenant is Benjamin Ruddierd, and his Lieutenant Colonel is that Loyal Gentleman Sir John Ogle.

And the other Regiment which formerly belonged to Col. Pury, is now conferred on Henry Lord Herbert, who≈øe Captain Lieutenant is,
Tho: Nawfan
Nathaniel Cole En≈øign
Thomas Pury Lieutenant Colonel
John Matthews Lieutenant
Edward Charleton En≈øign
Tho: French Major
John Thomas Lieut.
Alexander Coates En≈øign
Col. Roger Whitley, who hath done and ≈øuffered ≈øufficiently for his Maje≈øty, is Captain to Captain Phillips late Company
and Captain Griffantius Phillips Lieutenant.
Thomas Barnes En≈øign
William Coates Captain
_____
Boone Lieut:
Robert Da≈øhfield En≈øign
Thomas W ‚Ä¢ llward Capt.
_____
Jeanes Lieutenant
_____
Compton En≈øign
John Grove Captain
Thomas Jack≈øon Lieutenant
Arnold Whiffin En≈øign
Edward Winter Captain of Capt. Ellis late Company.
_____
Witterne Lieutenant
Henry Le≈øter Capt. to Capt. Greens late Company.
John Green Lieut.
Tho: Drake En≈øign
Richard Badeley Chirurgeon
Jenkin David Quarterma≈øter and Mar≈øhal.
Richard Ba≈øset Capt. of William Nea≈øt his Company.
Gabriel Holmes Lieutenant
Luke Thomas En≈øign

div.head: Adverti≈øement.
div.p: WHereas divers Riots have been committed by per≈øons di≈øgui≈ø'd in the night, in the Forrest of Duffeild Frith in the County of Derby, upon the Inheritance of Iohn Heale E≈øq (a Member of Parliament) and William Smith E≈øq both Gentlemen of his Maje≈øties Privy Chamber. The≈øe are to give notice, that whoever will declare the Authors, Actors, or Abettors of tho≈øe Riots to Mr. George Greg≈øon of Turneditch, or to Mr. Henry Smith of Denby neer Duffeild, they ≈øhall not only be remitted if they were Actors, but requited for the di≈øcovery, there being a Decree in the Exchequer, before the Lord Chief Baron (upon full hearing of Council on both ≈øides) again≈øt German Poole, George Poole, Miller, &c. the 16 of July la≈øt, and the former Decree in the Dutchy Court confirmed, whereof it was thought fit to give notice that none hereafter may run into future inconveniencies‚ñ™

div.head: Adverti≈øement.
div.p: WE are de≈øired to give notie that William Hall about 17 years old, is run away from his Ma≈øter Major Dennis and hath taken with him the ≈øum of 29 pounds. He is in Footmans habit of Grey Serge, edged with red, brown haire curld, not very long, and of pale complexion. If any can give notice of him, they may leave word with Mr. Samuel Mearne his Maje≈øties Bookbinder in Little Brittaine, and they ≈øhall be thankfully rewarded.

div.head:
From Argile≈øhire in Scotland
Aug. 13. 1660.
div.p: Here is very much rejoycing at the Impri≈øonment of the Marque≈øs of Argile: for though this Country bears his name, there are too many Families which he hath endeavored to ruine, the woful experience whereof will be evidenced by the Clandowgals, Clan Leans, Mac Donnals, and Mac Waughtons, be≈øides the unnatural and unhumane u≈øage of many hundred poor ≈øouls ≈øent by him into the I≈øland of Jura, where they all peri≈øhed. Whether he hath practi≈øed murther, and taking po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, you will hear ere long: I a≈ø≈øure you that thou≈øands are glad of what is done, who, although you yet have not their hands in this Letter, yet neither hands nor hearts will be wanting to pre≈øerve his Maje≈øties peace in Argile≈øhire again≈øt all oppo≈øers what≈øoever.

div.head: Hull.
div.p: His Maje≈øtie having been plea≈øed to Con≈øtitute the Lord Bela≈øy≈øe Lord Lieutenant of the Ea≈øt Ryding in York≈øhire, his Lord≈øhip ≈øummoned the Countrey to appear before him at Beverley the 13. of this in≈øtant Augu≈øt, together with his Deputy-Lieutenants, Ju≈øtices of the Peace, and chief Con≈øtables; where being met, they gave order for the rai≈øing the Trained Bands, being 3000. men, into three gallant Regiments, Commanded by Sir Francis Boynton, Sir John Hotham, and Mr. Wharton, as Colonels; and Sir Robert Hilliard Commands the Hor≈øe. The≈øe will all mu≈øter (in Bodies) before his Lord≈øhip within fifteen days after their Harve≈øt is over; the example whereof will be of great con≈øequence to other Counties, towards the ≈øettlement of the Ancient Legal way of Trained Bands for the ≈øecurity of the Kingdom.

This afternoon his Royal Highne≈øs the Duke of York was plea≈øed to bring with him the Duke of Glouce≈øter, the Duke of Albemarle, and ≈øeveral other per≈øons of Honor, to the hou≈øe of his Servant Captain Edmond Warcupp in Durham Yard, to accept the entertainmen ‚Ä¢ of a C ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ation.

After ≈øo many Changes of Officers in ≈øeveral Regiments, you may now take a Li≈øt of all the Officers in his Excellencies own Regiment, both Hor≈øe and Foot, wherein there is no mutation, his Grace having cho≈øen ≈øuch approved Officers as require no alteration.

list.head: George Monck Duke of Albermarle &c. Captain General of all his Maje≈øties Forces ‚Ä¢ n England, Scotland and Ireland, Colonel of a Regiment of Foot, his Captain Lieutenant is,
list.item: Ethelbert Morgan Lieut: col. and captain.

div.p: Ye≈øterday Augu≈øt 21.) the Gentlemen of the Artillery-ground for the City of London, having invited their Highne≈ø≈øes the Dukes of York and Gloce≈øter, they were accordingly entertained with the Duke of Buckingham, at Merchant Tayle ‚Ä¢ s Hall. Sir John Robin≈øon Lieut. of the Tower of London, leading them th ‚Ä¢ ther from St. Pauls Church, where they had a Sermon.
His Grace the Duke of Albemarle &c. is by the ≈øpecial favor of His Maje≈øty declared Lord Lievtenant of the Kingdome of Ireland.

His Grace the Duke of Alheniarle hath ≈øent Letters by His Maje≈øties command to the Engli≈øh Commi≈ø≈øioners in Scotland to cea≈øe any ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ther acting as Commi≈ø≈øioners after the 22 of this in≈øtant ‚Ä¢ ugu≈øt, the Government of Scotland being to be reduced to its ancient cour≈øe.

His Excellency notwith≈øtanding his con≈øtant abode at Court, hath as con≈øtant a watch and eye upon his Maje≈øties Army, and therefore taking notice that ≈øome Officers are too often ab≈øent from their Commands, whereby the wonted di≈øcipline of the Army will in time be much impaired, and ≈øeveral incident di≈øorders committed by Soldiers in the ab≈øence of their Commanders, hath for prevention thereof ≈øen ‚Ä¢ Orders to the Commi≈ø≈øiary General of the Mu≈øters to take care that no Troops or Companies be mu≈øtered, where two Commi≈øsion-Officers are not pre≈øent, who upon examination have not continued at their re≈øpective charges; whereof we are commanded to give notice, that no Officer may pretend ignorance.

His Excellency hath given expre≈øs order, that no new men Officers or Soldiers be taken into any Troop or Company, or continued (be they of never ≈øo antient ≈øtanding) that have not or ≈øhall not take the Oaths of Supremacy and Allegiance to his Maje≈øty; wherein his Excellency is re≈øolved to take ≈øtrict account, being informed that ≈øome new Officers and Soldiers are privately li≈øted who had not taken the ≈øaid oaths; the ≈øeveral Mu≈øter ma≈øters being to pa≈øs none but ≈øuch, whom they are a≈ø≈øured have taken the ≈øaid oaths of Supremacy and Allegiance.
London, Printed by John Macock, and Tho: Mewcomb, 1660.
